raw_docs: 1 introduction. this final surrender report details exploration activities undertaken by sandfire resources limited (sandfire) on the murchison combined reporting group (c 35/2015) between the first grant date of 19 june 2014 and the final surrender date of all tenements, 22 november 2023 (the reporting period). the exploration licences overlie favourable stratigraphy within the mineral-rich bryah basin, and are considered to be prospective for volcanogenic massive-sulfide (vms)-style cu-au-ag mineralisation. 2 location and access. the murchison project (the project) is located approximately 70 to 90 km north to nne of meekatharra, 20 to 40 km south to southwest of the historical peak hill copper and gold mining centre, and 70 to 90 km southwest of sandfire’s degrussa cu-au mine. access to the project is via the great northern highway, ashburton downs- meekatharra road or the meekatharra-mount clare road, then by pastoral tracks. these tracks may be closed to vehicles during wet periods. 3 tenement details. 3.1 tenements. exploration licences 51/1647, 51/1672, 51/1673, 51/1702, 51/1759, 51/1805, 51/1967, 51/1968, 52/2880, 52/2881 and 52/3330 made up the murchison combined reporting group, c 35/2015. tenement details are listed in table 3.1. on 4 april 2022 a partial relinquishment of 14 graticule blocks on e 52/3330 was registered with dmirs. a total of 21 blocks remained. an outright surrender of exploration licences 51/1647, 51/1672, 51/1673, 51/1702, 51/1759, 51/1805, 51/1967, 51/1968, 52/2880, 52/2881 and 52/3330 was registered with dmirs on 22 november 2023. 3.2 landholders. the murchison project covers vacant crown land and partly encroaches on mt padbury pastoral lease (3114/1134), southwest of peak hill. the lessees of mt padbury pastoral lease, brian garrity, james harvey nichols and william robert nichols, were advised of the relevant grants. 3.3 native title. the majority of the tenements that make up the murchison project are located within the wajarri yamatji native title claim (wc04/010), with the exception of e 52/3330 which is located within the nharnuwangga wajarri ngarlawangga native title determination (wcd00/001). an alternative standard heritage agreement was negotiated with the wajarri yamatji native title claim during the application process,

lease (3114/1134), southwest of peak hill. the lessees of mt padbury pastoral lease, brian garrity, james harvey nichols and william robert nichols, were advised of the relevant grants. 3.3 native title. the majority of the tenements that make up the murchison project are located within the wajarri yamatji native title claim (wc04/010), with the exception of e 52/3330 which is located within the nharnuwangga wajarri ngarlawangga native title determination (wcd00/001). an alternative standard heritage agreement was negotiated with the wajarri yamatji native title claim during the application process, which subsequently allowed for the grant of the relevant tenements pursuant to section 29 of the native title act 1992 (cth). sandfire maintains an existing claim-wide settlement deed and heritage agreement with the nharnuwangga wajarri ngarlawangga native title determination. heritage surveys were undertaken during 2018 and 2019. 4 geology. 4.1 regional geology. the murchison project tenements are underlain by the lower proterozoic volcanic sedimentary basin sequence previously known as the glengarry group (gee, 1987), deposited on archaean basement. revisions of the geology in the late 1990’s-early 2000’s by occhipinti et al. (1998) and pirajno et al. (2004) led to the subdivision of the lower proterozoic sequence into four distinct basins: yerrida, bryah, padbury and earaheedy. the pull-apart (proto-oceanic) basin into which these formations were deposited was controlled by major basement strike-slip faults that created a complex array of horsts and grabens. this fault array controlled sedimentation, volcanism, and later, structural complexity. the time frame from initiation of the basin to its closure was in the order of 150 million years (jeffrey, 2011). the bryah basin sequence contains deformed and metamorphosed mafic-ultramafic volcanic rocks, and chemical and siliciclastic sedimentary rocks within four formations, two of which are present over the tenement area: the karalundi and narracoota formations (pirajno and occhipinti, 1998). in mapping of the peak hill 1:250,000 sheet the geological survey of western australia (gswa) described the karalundi formation as a mixed clastic-carbonate, chert-tuff sequence, lying conformably between the doolgunna arkose and the narracoota volcanics in the southern part of the bryah basin, that represents a transition from a shallow-water marine environment to a rift environment, and the commencement of basalt volcanism. the narracoota formation conformably overlies the karalundi formation in the type area, which is specified

the karalundi and narracoota formations (pirajno and occhipinti, 1998). in mapping of the peak hill 1:250,000 sheet the geological survey of western australia (gswa) described the karalundi formation as a mixed clastic-carbonate, chert-tuff sequence, lying conformably between the doolgunna arkose and the narracoota volcanics in the southern part of the bryah basin, that represents a transition from a shallow-water marine environment to a rift environment, and the commencement of basalt volcanism. the narracoota formation conformably overlies the karalundi formation in the type area, which is specified as the mikhaburra-cashman area, 10-15 km south of narracoota homestead (gee, 1978).the narracoota formation is the volcanic component of the bryah basin sequence. hynes and gee (1986) reported on the petrochemistry and tectonic setting of the narracoota metabasaltic rocks. they concluded that they have fairly uniform chemistry and are of mid-ocean-ridge basalt (morb) affinity, although the original mafic volcanic rocks may have been emplaced through the rifting of continental crust. also noted were the presence of ultramafic members (high-mg basalts and komatiite). massive iron-copper-gold vms deposits are located within rift facies mafic volcanic rocks. they are hosted close to the base of a volcano-sedimentary facies and closely spatially related to faults. epigenetic gold deposits formed later in the tectonic evolution, and are related to structures and reactivated faults. these are not stratigraphically controlled, but are a combination of structural and lithological control. the project area lies near the southern margin of the bryah basin sequence, where it is in faulted contact with the yerrida basin sequence. 4.2 local geology. lithologies represented within the project area are quartz wacke and conglomerate of the karalundi formation, overlain by predominantly mafic and ultramafic schists, and basaltic hyaloclastite derived from volcanics of the narracoota formation. from the detailed gswa 1:100,000 scale mapping, the karalundi formation includes chert, siltstone, calcareous siltstone, cross-bedded and ferruginous arenite, litharenite, purple, green, and black shale, and minor quartz-pebble conglomerate lenses. the narracoota formation conformably overlies and locally interfingers with the karalundi formation, and can be subdivided on texture, geochemistry, and petrology, into mafic schist, ultramafic schist, and basaltic hyaloclastite. the first two lithotypes are characterised by a pervasive schistosity, and the distinction between mafic and ultramafic

formation. from the detailed gswa 1:100,000 scale mapping, the karalundi formation includes chert, siltstone, calcareous siltstone, cross-bedded and ferruginous arenite, litharenite, purple, green, and black shale, and minor quartz-pebble conglomerate lenses. the narracoota formation conformably overlies and locally interfingers with the karalundi formation, and can be subdivided on texture, geochemistry, and petrology, into mafic schist, ultramafic schist, and basaltic hyaloclastite. the first two lithotypes are characterised by a pervasive schistosity, and the distinction between mafic and ultramafic composition can only be ascertained geochemically. the mafic-ultramafic schist includes actinolite-tremolite schist and chlorite schist. metadolerite dykes and sills, metabasaltic breccia, and minor metapyroxenite lenses are contained within the schists, and although these rocks are not internally deformed, they are included in the schist lithotype. within the mafic-ultramafic schist, good exposures of variably deformed pillowed meta-basalt (ean) may be observed. in addition, pods and lenses of jasperoidal chert are, in places, associated with the volcanic rocks, and they may represent hot spring chemical precipitates (eanc). the metabasaltic hyaloclastites (eanh) are undeformed, dominantly of mafic composition, and have a spilitic character. both formations are overlain by cainozoic alluvium and colluvium cover sediments. 5 previous exploration activities. a significant number of companies have undertaken exploration activities in and around the project area, from the late 1970’s until the present day. these companies include hunter resources, lac minerals, samantha exploration, homestake, western mining, king mining corporation, geopeko, curtin mining, st barbara mines, north exploration, eagle gold mines, grosvenor gold, helix resources, richmond mining, dominion, afmeco, cra, eagle ridge, anglo australian resources, titan resources, oryx resources, gleneagle gold, troy resources, sabminco, golden cross operations, plutonic operations and latin gold. since the mid-1980s this exploration has been focussed primarily on base metals, primarily copper, and gold. 6 current exploration activities. 6.1 geophysical survey. 6.1.1 heliborne em survey. within the 2016-17 reporting period sandfire commissioned new resolution geophysics (nrg) to fly a 200 m spaced heliborne electromagnetic (em) survey across several areas, including a portion of e 51/1672. the operations report is attached in appendix 1. 6.1.2 airborne magnetic survey. during the 2017-18 reporting period

troy resources, sabminco, golden cross operations, plutonic operations and latin gold. since the mid-1980s this exploration has been focussed primarily on base metals, primarily copper, and gold. 6 current exploration activities. 6.1 geophysical survey. 6.1.1 heliborne em survey. within the 2016-17 reporting period sandfire commissioned new resolution geophysics (nrg) to fly a 200 m spaced heliborne electromagnetic (em) survey across several areas, including a portion of e 51/1672. the operations report is attached in appendix 1. 6.1.2 airborne magnetic survey. during the 2017-18 reporting period sandfire commissioned a detailed airborne magnetic survey (registration #71385) covering a portion of the prospective bryah stratigraphy, including the entire murchison combined reporting group. the extent of the survey is shown in figure 6.6. imagery is presented in figure 6.7. the operations report is attached in appendix 1. the magnetic imagery added significantly to the geological understanding of the area. 6.1.3 ground gravity survey. a portion of the murchison project was covered by a regional-scale bryah basin ground gravity survey during the 2018-19 reporting period. the survey was undertaken by atlas geophysics under the direction of newexco services pty ltd. the gravity data provided a far greater level of resolution to existing data., and added significant value to the understanding of the area. gravity data and reports are included in appendix 2. 6.1.4 moving loop electromagnetic survey. the eastern titles of the murchison project (e 51/1647 and e 51/1672) were covered by a basin-scale moving loop electromagnetic (mlem) survey between 2019 and 2020. the mlem logistics report is included in appendix 3. 6.2 rock chip sampling. 19 rock chip samples were collected from available outcrop. rock chips were analysed by icp-ms (inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry) and icp-es (inductively coupled plasma emission spectrometry) after aqua regia digest by bureau veritas minerals (formerly ultratrace) in perth and returned no significant copper or gold anomalism. location and assay data are attached in appendix 4. 6.3 drilling. drilling was conducted across several titles as part of a broader ‘enterprise farm-in’ exploration project. drilling aimed to identify prospective stratigraphy in the interpreted location of the karalundi and naracoota formations, and to provide quality geochemical information across the area. drilling locations are shown in figure 6.10. drilling and assay data are attached in appendix 4. 6.3.1 ac drilling – ruby well project. between

veritas minerals (formerly ultratrace) in perth and returned no significant copper or gold anomalism. location and assay data are attached in appendix 4. 6.3 drilling. drilling was conducted across several titles as part of a broader ‘enterprise farm-in’ exploration project. drilling aimed to identify prospective stratigraphy in the interpreted location of the karalundi and naracoota formations, and to provide quality geochemical information across the area. drilling locations are shown in figure 6.10. drilling and assay data are attached in appendix 4. 6.3.1 ac drilling – ruby well project. between august 2017 and april 2019 sandfire drilled 521 air core (ac) holes (for a total of 35,425 m) over e 51/1647, e 51/1672 and e 51/1673. drilling was intended to identify prospective stratigraphy, and to infill across the prospective lithologies to determine geochemistry and identify anomalies. this was complicated in the area by the possible presence of outliers of the earaheedy group mount leake formation, which unconformably overlies the prospective bryah group. lithologies intersected included sandstone and siltstone of the doolgunna formation, sedimentary breccia and conglomerate, siltstone and sandstone, lithic wacke, mafic-derived breccia, minor chert and jaspilite, dolerite and basalt of the karalundi formation, and narracoota formation basalt. small intercepts of trace disseminated pyrite occurred sporadically in some drill holes. no significant anomalism was detected. as shown in figure 6.11, the ac drilling shows end-of-hole lithologies of two broad types; a mafic volcano-sedimentary sequence (karalundi fm), and a more massive basalt package (naracoota fm). this broadly matches the regional interpretation, and clearly correlates to the airborne magnetic imagery. several interesting anomalous assay results were intersected. assay results in general did not delineate broad trends. 6.3.2 rc drilling – ruby well project. one rc drillhole (efrc0044) was drilled to 346 m to test beneath anomalous gold and copper geochemistry intersected in ac drillhole efac2007, within prospective stratigraphy of the upper karalundi formation. efrc0044 did not return further significant results. 6.3.2.1 dhem. downhole electromagnetic (dhem) survey was conducted on efrc0044, by merlin geophysics using a digiatlantis tool from 30 to 340 m downhole. a moderate, short wavelength mid to late time response was detected, relating to a moderate magnetic response extending off-hole. no further work was recommended by sandfire’s geophysical consultants (firth, 2019). dhem data and reports

to test beneath anomalous gold and copper geochemistry intersected in ac drillhole efac2007, within prospective stratigraphy of the upper karalundi formation. efrc0044 did not return further significant results. 6.3.2.1 dhem. downhole electromagnetic (dhem) survey was conducted on efrc0044, by merlin geophysics using a digiatlantis tool from 30 to 340 m downhole. a moderate, short wavelength mid to late time response was detected, relating to a moderate magnetic response extending off-hole. no further work was recommended by sandfire’s geophysical consultants (firth, 2019). dhem data and reports are included in appendix 5. 6.3.3 ac drilling – murchison prospect. between april and november 2019 sandfire drilled 336 ac holes (for a total of 28,732 m) over e 51/1702, e 51/1759, e 52/2880 and e 52/2881. drilling was conducted over the bryah south prospect as part of a first pass 800 m x 100 m drill pattern designed to test interpreted karalundi and narracoota formations below untested cover north of the previously-drilled enterprise prospect, and to improve the geological understanding of the area prior to future drill programs. drilling intersected significant tholeiitic and high-magnesium basalts, with lesser siltstone, quartz arenite and black shale, interpreted to be of the narracoota formation. significant basalt and dolerite were intersected in the southwest part of the drilling program; thick packages of sedimentary breccia, siltstone, arenite and wacke and minor carbonaceous sediments were intersected moving towards the northeast. the mafic units intersected were interpreted to be of the narracoota formation, however this was questioned due to the variability of geology intersected. several interesting anomalous assay results were intersected. assay results in general did not delineate broad trends. 6.3.4 petrography. five drill samples were dispatched for petrographic analysis by mason geoscience, to determine lithology, alteration and texture in fine grained rocks which can be difficult visually in drill cuttings. petrographic samples are summarised in table 6.7. petrographic reports are included in appendix 6. 6.4 remote sensing. 6.4.1 aerial photography. sandfire commissioned the capture of detailed regional scale aerial photography over the cheroona and west bryah project areas, by aerometrex, as job no. a6204. the extent of aerial photography is shown in figure 6.12. imagery was captured as 15 cm gsd orthophotography with a horizontal accuracy of +/- 0.3 m, and delivered to sandfire as a redgreen-blue (i.e. true colour) mosaic. a digital terrain

rocks which can be difficult visually in drill cuttings. petrographic samples are summarised in table 6.7. petrographic reports are included in appendix 6. 6.4 remote sensing. 6.4.1 aerial photography. sandfire commissioned the capture of detailed regional scale aerial photography over the cheroona and west bryah project areas, by aerometrex, as job no. a6204. the extent of aerial photography is shown in figure 6.12. imagery was captured as 15 cm gsd orthophotography with a horizontal accuracy of +/- 0.3 m, and delivered to sandfire as a redgreen-blue (i.e. true colour) mosaic. a digital terrain model (dtm) was generated using automated photogrammetry with manual adjustment to correct major errors, generally associated with significant vegetation at creek lines. the dtm was then contoured to produce 0.5 m and 2.5 m contour sets. acquired imagery is shown in figure 6.13. imagery, dtm and contour data was submitted to dmirs and registered in the magix airborne survey register with the registration number r71305 under reporting policy conditions. aerial photography advanced the logistical understanding of the project area. 6.4.2 remote sensing end-member mapping. sandfire's consultants undertook a remote sensing exercise observing multi-spectral satellite imagery across a portion of the basins to correlate known mineralisation with observed surface spectral responses. sentinel-2 short-wave infra-red (swir) data, aster very near infrared (vnir), and long wavelength infrared (lwir) data were acquired for the areas of interest. the technique used assumes that the signal from each pixel is a combination of up to 16 ‘end members’. the technique estimates relative spectral abundances for these ‘end members’ (spectral unmixing), and these are then compared to a usgs spectral library of 481 minerals to assign identifications. these end members are compared to known occurrences of minerals sought, in this case copper and gold, to define correlation to mineralisation and then a probabilistic map of copper and gold targets is generated. inaccuracies which might occur in the spectral unmixing process are offset by the correlation to known prospects whereby the exact identification of minerals is less significant than the relative relationship to known prospects. an example of the results of remote sensing end-member mapping is shown in figure 6.14. 7 conclusions and recommendations. the murchison group titles are considered prospective for vms mineralisation due to their location within the mineral-rich bryah and padbury basins. exploration indicated the presence and location

probabilistic map of copper and gold targets is generated. inaccuracies which might occur in the spectral unmixing process are offset by the correlation to known prospects whereby the exact identification of minerals is less significant than the relative relationship to known prospects. an example of the results of remote sensing end-member mapping is shown in figure 6.14. 7 conclusions and recommendations. the murchison group titles are considered prospective for vms mineralisation due to their location within the mineral-rich bryah and padbury basins. exploration indicated the presence and location of prospective strata in bedrock in some areas of the project. however, no significant anomalism was detected. with the recent completion of underground mining operations at degrussa, and sandfire’s acquisition of the matsa copper operations, the company determined that it was an appropriate time to assess all commercial opportunities, including potential sale of the bryah basin projects. as announced to the asx on 9 december 2022, sandfire initiated a formal sale process for the degrussa copper operations and related exploration tenure. a reduction in company budget led to the decision for sandfire to surrender the murchison project titles.
